physDesc.p: This letter is three pages long. It is typed on Amy Lowell’s stationary, with the engraved heading “Miss A. Lowell, Heath Street, Brookline, Mass.”

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following: WWI

div.p: You surprise and distress me very much by refusing to take the "Bombardment." Particularly at this time when the fall of Antwerp makes it so very [appropriate]. Naturally I supposed when you wrote and telegraphed for it in such a hurry that you fully intended to take it. "The Bombardment" was written after I sent you The Allies” the first time, and as soon as I had done it I realized that the two should never be separated. I was on the point of sending itthem to Margaret Anderson, who has so keenkind an idea of my merits as never to refuse what I send her, when your letter and telegram came, and my loyalty to "Poetry" made me decide to give you the preference.

A disagreeable thought has come into my mind, and I think it always better to say things right out when you feel them, so you will pardon me if I tell you that I fear it is because of the number of pages which the two poems would take, and the consequent size of the check which you would have to pay me, which has determined your decision. I
need not point out to you how manifestly unfair such a course would be, onlyas, it seems to me, Ishould I be obliged to suggest that I have already paid to your magazine in gifts and advertisements more than I have ever earned from it.

It seems to me that theSurely a labourer is worthy of his hire. It may be a sad fact that I have so much, and others whom you think as worthy, so little. Life is not fair, and neither are editors. Yours will not be the first magazine which has tried to dock my pay. I only ask what everyone asks, to be taken on my own merits regardless of my surroundings. It is a position you would not deny the beggar. I wish I could see so honest a democratic spirit in the world that they would not deny it to the man with enough means to live upon.

I know "The Bombardment" to be the best poem of the two and therefore I can conceive no reason why you should refuse to take it in except lack of space. In your original advertisement you agreed sometimes to give one poet the whole number. This, so far as I know, you have only done once. and+ I can assure you that these two poemsthese poems will [not sure] half of a [not sure].
They will make a great impression on the public, particularly if they are put together, and it seems hard therefore that they should not have that opportunity.
If I am wrong in my suspicions I beg you to forgive me, but indeed you have no idea how difficult it is to be treated fairly when people know that you are not living on what you earn.
